Proud Urburgh!  once fam'd city of this land,</br>Where golden ease repaid th' industrious hand;</br>Where commerce flourish'd, and where learning grew;</br>And wealth, and taste, and grandeur, charm'd the view;</br>Where life in all its joys and sorrows past,</br>Guarded by power that promised long to last;</br>Where fickle fashions daily lur'd the sight,</br>And noisy mirth disturb'd the sleep of night;</br>Where scenes of splendour fir'd the blazing square,</br>Sought by the great, and crowded by the fair:</br>Thou seat of elegance, and every art</br>That could delight, seduce, or mend the heart:</br>So late in glory tow'ring to the skies,</br>How art thou fallen now, no more to rise!</br>In splendid ruin still alive to fame,</br>Thy giant wreck shall long preserve thy name!

Memory, awake!  amidst thy stores retrace</br>The former bustle of this lonely place;</br>There, as in life, I view the motley crowd,</br>In hurry and confusion swift and loud:—</br>The fools of fashion, idolizing dress—</br>The tatter'd form that wither'd in distress—</br>The idle loiterers that loung'd along—</br>The group that listen'd to the minstrel's song—</br>The Postman hast'ning with his letter'd store,</br>Oft watch'd by anxious eyes from door to door,</br>Whose sacred charge of business — friendship — love—</br>A source of sorrow or delight would prove—</br>To wake distress — despair — or bid them cease;</br>Herald of ill — or messenger of peace:</br>Or warm with all th' affection of the heart,</br>That fate had doom'd from all it lov'd to part.</br>The active Tradesman, jostling through the street,</br>Who scarce could stop a passing friend to greet—</br>Boys, seeking play in ev'ry roomy spot,</br>The stern command to hasten, heeded not—</br>The prancing steed, whose eye shot fire around,</br>Whose iron tread flash'd o'er the flinty ground—</br>The crowd around some casual scene of woe,</br>Where few reliev'd what many sought to know—</br>And children following each unusual sight,</br>Gazing with vacant wonder and delight!</br>How often have I seen the hurrying throng,</br>In ceaseless line, these pavements pass along;</br>As if the world had urg'd her myriads here,</br>As to a spot unknown to pain and fear.</br>How often have I heard, with echoing feet</br>The sons of labour tread the twilight street;</br>Or caught the sigh of friendless, houseless woe,</br>Crouch'd at a door, or wand'ring faint and slow.</br>Oft, at that early hour, each fabric round</br>Shook with the waggons grating on the ground,</br>That slowly brought the gifts of Ceres' hand</br>To feed th' insatiate mistress of the land;</br>While chariots rattling as they roll'd along,</br>Bore the last lingerers from the festive throng.

Here oft returning from the social board,</br>Where friendship all its inspiration pour'd,</br>With mind at once enliven'd and reliev'd,</br>And by the rapid flight of time deceiv'd,—</br>Homeward I trod each solitary street,</br>Whose silence echo'd to my hast'ning feet.</br>Perchance around the full orb'd, welcome Moon,</br>Pour'd from the arch of heaven night's silver noon;</br>Then, as I past, the shadow'd domes I trac'd,</br>And o'er reflected roofs and turrets pac'd;</br>And walls and spires, that seem'd my path to pave,</br>Like sails and masts upon the moonlight wave!

Here oft, with feelings that can ne'er return,</br>I view'd the hero's tomb — the patriot's urn—</br>The vast Cathedral, solemn to the eye—</br>The trophied column tow'ring to the sky—</br>The House rever'd where senates held debate,</br>On whose decisions hung the nation's fate;</br>For whom, alas!  that rev'rence lives no more;</br>'Tis now but to remember — and deplore!</br>There love of power and lust of gold inspir'd,</br>And left but few with patriot virtue fir'd:</br>And thence the nation first receiv'd the blow</br>That laid her hopes, and strength, and glories low.</br>Its less'ning line of arch the bridge still shows,</br>And o'er the wave it's giant shadow throws,</br>Though scarce a lonely wand'rer hails its view,</br>Nor vessel stoops her sail while gliding through.

Here stood a home to shield the poor and old,</br>Where childhood play'd, and age long stories told—</br>Where some who trod the busy paths of life,</br>In sorrow clos'd it's round of care and strife;</br>Whose past bright days, in bitter contrast brought,</br>Form'd the last efforts of expiring thought!</br>Collected here the wreck of human kind—</br>The shatter'd frame, and the exhausted mind;</br>The hopeless spirit, and the sunder'd heart,</br>By anguish and misfortune wrench'd apart—</br>In ev'ry stage of slow or swift decay,</br>Past the dim hours of life's autumnal day;</br>Falling like dry and yellow leaves around,</br>And soon, like them, to mingle with the ground!</br>There musing melancholy silent sate,</br>Pond'ring the dark vicissitudes of fate;</br>And brooding on the past in madd'ning thought,</br>When life with hope and energy was fraught.</br>There nerveless palsy shook her trembling head,</br>And hoary childhood prest his constant bed—</br>There the half maniac mus'd his dreaming day,</br>And idiotism laugh'd its life away!</br>And thence the young, of parentage unknown,</br>With hopes, and fears, and feelings all their own,</br>Launch'd out on life's rough sea, unaided and alone!

The scenes where pleasure held her fairy reign,</br>And bound the laughing groups in flow'ry chain;</br>From whom th' unnumber'd hours too swiftly fled—</br>For whom too soon the morn its twilight shed—</br>The floor which beauty press'd in mazy dance,</br>And blest her followers with a casual glance—</br>The lounge where idlers stroll'd away a noon,</br>And walks where lovers whisper'd to the Moon—</br>The tasteful shops that lin'd the crowded street,</br>And busy docks that hail'd th' approaching fleet—</br>The public gallery of cherish'd art,</br>Whose beauties soften'd and sublim'd the heart—</br>The palace where the monarch sat enthron'd,</br>And the barr'd prison where the felon groan'd—</br>All — all are fall'n!  and desolation reigns,</br>Where flourish'd once the mistress of the plains!

Urburgh!  thy suburbs were a scene of joy</br>The morrow's doubtful ills could not destroy!</br>When summer evening rob'd the gorgeous sky,</br>And day was loveliest as it fled the eye,</br>Passing away in many a crimson streak,</br>Like the last flush on dying beauty's cheek,—</br>The fields were crowded by a mingled throng,</br>The young, the gay, the active, and the strong.</br>There careless boys, and men releas'd from care,</br>In varied pastime, woo'd the evening air—</br>There life exhibited her brightest face,</br>And thoughtless pleasure laugh'd in ev'ry place—</br>There, ere the Moon her snowy radiance shed,</br>Linger'd the student ere he sought his bed—</br>And there the servant, loos'd from masters' chain,</br>Awhile forgot that servitude was pain.</br>While merchants urg'd their dusty wheels from town,</br>To breathe the country air on beds of down,</br>Children in groups were homeward seen to creep,</br>With lagging steps and eyes half clos'd in sleep;</br>Or mark'd with sorrow that th' approach of night</br>Had shut the sport so early from their sight.

Then, Urburgh!  glorious was thy perfect day;</br>Along thy river's banks what navies lay,</br>To waft the produce of thy land away;</br>Or laden with the fruits of other shores,</br>To feed thy luxuries and swell thy stores.</br>Thy roads, like rays that from a centre fly,</br>To ev'ry point diverging, met the eye;</br>Whence all the country pour'd its wealth to town,</br>And constant traffic rattled up and down.</br>From thence th' approaching rustics with amaze</br>Turn'd on thy numerous spires their eager gaze;</br>And urg'd with anxious haste their steps along,</br>To view thy wonders, and to join thy throng.</br>What bustle did thy crowded inns display,</br>Where ceaseless business claim'd the restless day.</br>How rich thy streets!  where trade, to lure the eye,</br>And tempt the wealthy as they loiter'd by,</br>Brought from all climes to one capacious mart,</br>The gifts of nature, and the works of art—</br>The glitt'ring metals, shap'd unnumber'd ways,</br>And jewels darting all their varied rays;</br>And robes, the rich and lovely to adorn,</br>Whose fashions liv'd a night, and died at morn—</br>All pride, caprice, or fancy could require;</br>And all that pamper'd sense could e'en desire;</br>The sails of commerce wafted o'er the main,</br>From Arctic seas, and India's sultry plain;</br>Earth's farthest realms, at thy supreme command,</br>Yielded their stores to deck thy golden land.</br>When day-light sunk behind the western shore,</br>Thy lights appear'd a second day to pour;</br>Whose countless rays, reflected on the eye,</br>Seem'd like a distant fire that blush'd on high,</br>And almost chas'd the darkness from the sky.

Here all was intellectual — glowing — bright!</br>No winter of the soul — no dearth — no night!</br>Earth had no wisdom that was stranger here—</br>In art no rival — and in joy no peer.</br>The land's etherial part; in sanguine hour,</br>Here came each fiery soul, and rose to power;</br>Till science soaring reach'd her highest aim,</br>And pour'd o'er all the world a mental flame.</br>The country seem'd but made to yield the best</br>Of art and nature to adorn her crest;</br>The willing slave to spread her ample board,</br>With all the field, the garden, could afford.</br>Howe'er the peasant lov'd his sunny scene,</br>Boasted his cloudless skies, and verdant green,</br>Once cherish'd here, he slighted, or forgot,</br>The listless quiet of the lowly cot;</br>And found his soul in spell of magic bound,</br>By more intense delights that spread around.</br>For him the silent glen had charms no more,</br>He came to wonder — tarried to adore!</br>There life was sameness — here 'twas ever new,</br>With fresh excitement op'ning on his view—</br>There lack of thought had dimm'd his vacant hours.</br>While here his soul had scope for all her powers.

Yes, beauty o'er the rural prospect reigns,</br>Clothes the fair fields, and brightens all the plains.</br>'Tis joy to breathe the pure and fragrant air,</br>And see the sun revel in glory there;</br>To view the clouds in fairy form and hue,</br>And the fields glitt'ring in a sea of dew;</br>To see the yellow morn its wings unfold,</br>And ev'ning set in crimson and in gold;</br>To tread the silent dell in pensive mood,</br>And stray by moonlight through the thoughtful wood;</br>To be in solitude, but scarce alone,</br>Circled by forms that still are fancy's own;</br>To climb the mountain wild, and see below</br>The landscape stretching in the sunny glow,</br>Till, fading in the horizon's misty blue,</br>It seems to melt in clouds, and dies from view;</br>To hear the distant hum — the murm'ring stream,</br>And wander lost in many a joyous dream:</br>These are high pleasures, and who feels them not,</br>Who views creation as a blank, or blot,</br>Must own a soul of cold and midnight form,</br>That thought can never thrill, nor feeling warm.</br>But still these beauties pall upon the sense;</br>The sated mind asks something more intense;</br>Some more etherial, intellectual scope,</br>To rouse the fancy, and inspire with hope;</br>To wake — to fire — to agitate the soul,</br>Until she burn and revel past controul;</br>Sweeping her own created empire round,</br>That owns no law, acknowledges no bound—</br>But, unsubstantial as herself, displays</br>Unearthly scenes in fancy's brightest blaze!</br>And hence she flies, where kindred minds inspire,</br>And still in cities lights up all her fire.

Here, while the spendthrift met a summer friend,</br>And many a syren lur'd him to his end;</br>The sons of art inspiring favor found,</br>And saw their toils with wealth and honor crown'd:</br>And here, rewarded by the public hand,</br>The man of genius felt his powers expand;</br>Heard his proud country echo with his name,</br>And left life's last — best gift — a deathless fame!</br>And here his eloquence the speaker pour'd</br>To breathless crowds, who listen'd and ador'd:</br>Now softly flowing like the glassy stream—</br>Now loud as angry seas th' impetuous theme!</br>With stormy passions then the breast he fir'd,</br>Or souls with love of liberty inspir'd;</br>Then with deep pathos forc'd the melting sigh,</br>And drew the tear in many an answering eye.

Here, when the day approach'd its welcome close,</br>And wearied tradesmen gave their minds repose;</br>Where the snug Tavern spread its seats around,</br>And cheerful fire, and lively groups were found</br>Each smiling met his neighbour and his friend,</br>A social hour, releas'd from care, to spend:</br>Where evening stole in varied talk away,</br>And mirth and friendship sped the parting day.</br>The fancied soldier plann'd lost fields to win,</br>Though he ne'er heard the battle's distant din:</br>While politicians held prolong'd debates,</br>And managed in idea mighty states;</br>Glad, as the horn proclaim'd the newsman near,</br>Some fresh accounts from foreign climes to hear;</br>To judge who next might break a despot's yoke;</br>What army strike some scarce expected stroke;</br>Turning their arms that liberty to aid;</br>That tyrants hoped was vanquish'd or betray'd.</br>Some conn'd what taxes next would press the land,</br>And wrest the fruits of labor from the hand:</br>Whether the peace they pray'd would e'er return</br>Man cease to slaughter man, or cities burn.</br>There the pretended patriot found his due;</br>And public measures met severe review:</br>The Prince himself, in censure nothing spar'd,</br>Had there his follies or his crimes declar'd.</br>The wiser few discours'd of nature's laws,</br>Of operations, and effect, and cause;</br>While shafts of wit, in harmless strife assail'd,</br>And manly sense, and tow'ring thought prevail'd.</br>Then, too, (when day went down in gold and pink,)</br>When some were met to talk, and some to drink;</br>Dress'd for the night, the noble and the fair</br>Sought the gay scene in chariot and in chair;</br>Where taste and wealth conspir'd to yield delight,</br>And cards and concerts wing'd away the night;</br>Where life's refinement strove its best to shew,</br>And man the brightest polish man can know.

When welcome Sunday brought the lab'rer rest,</br>And shed its peace in many a weary breast—</br>(Sole morn that does not break on care and strife—</br>Toil's halcyon dawn — the holiday of life!)</br>On that blest day, in all their best array'd,</br>Th' industrious poor their virtuous pride display'd.</br>For six long, joyles suns in gloom immers'd,</br>The rescued race in field and street dispers'd;</br>Leaving their humble homes, with laughing eye,</br>To breathe pure air, and see a brighter sky.</br>The modest wife hung on her husband's arm,</br>With every virtue grac'd, and every charm;</br>Glad to embrace a summer hour to roam,</br>And leave her sorrows and her cares at home:</br>While sporting round their path their children trod,</br>Freed from the terrors of the tyrant rod!</br>That day were seen the humble and the high,</br>Alike ambitious of the public eye;</br>In whose gay promenade 'twere hard to tell</br>Which in the mansion or the cot might dwell.</br>Propitious day!  a holiday to all!</br>A heaven to those who own'd religion's call!</br>Had no divine command that day design'd</br>To rest the limb, and sooth by pray'r the mind;</br>Still would I honor with the meed of praise</br>The man, who rescued from life's stormy days</br>Those welcome intervals of rest and peace,</br>When labor sleeps, and care and bustle cease;</br>That, like the springs amidst a desert plain,</br>Refresh the traveller for his toil again;</br>That break life's long, dull uniformity,</br>And set awhile the prison'd spirit free!</br>Like verdant isles along the ocean spread,</br>Or streams of light o'er clouds of darkness shed;</br>It dawns upon the lab'ring multitude,</br>An ever-look'd for, never-failing good!</br>Each day, whose darkness makes it doubly dear,</br>Seems but to struggle on to bring it near;</br>It comes like friendship to the captive's cell—</br>And for its little season — all is well!</br>And though like joy it swiftly glide away—</br>The next can scarce be thought a distant day.</br>Beneath each dome, where men their God ador'd,</br>What melting eloquence the preacher pour'd!</br>The guilty heart was shaken in its seat;</br>And seem'd to rend the breast in which it beat;</br>And tears — unbidden tears — suffus'd the eyes</br>That lately flash'd defiance at the skies.</br>While some implor'd the wicked to repent—</br>Others, on doubtful points of doctrine bent,</br>In mystery's mazes led and lost the mind,</br>That in the labyrinth no path could find.</br>The wiser part would man's clear duties teach,</br>And heaven's sublime and plain commandments preach:</br>Declare its doom when harden'd sinners die—</br>And lead the penitent to bliss on high:</br>Chusing the solemn and appropriate hour,</br>To blend instruction with religion's power;</br>While mute attention list'ning crowds bestow'd,</br>Whose hearts were melted and whose bosoms glow'd!</br>When o'er the sense the spell of music stole,</br>Seraphic rapture fir'd the rising soul!</br>A sacred flame through mortal fibres ran;</br>And heavenly feelings thrill'd the breast of man!</br>But now the prayer is hush'd!  the hearers fled—</br>The worship ended, and devotion dead:</br>Such is the boon that discord leaves below;</br>Her tread an earthquake and her visit woe.

Mistaken statesmen!  who on wars rely,</br>And to ambition all your powers apply,</br>In vain you boast your king's — your country's good,</br>While wasteful of her treasure and her blood:</br>In vain your armies vanquish distant coasts,</br>Your country's vigour dies 'midst all her boasts</br>How vain — while healthful labor quits her fields—</br>How vain the trophies ev'ry conquest yields;</br>How worse than vain th' unprofitable show,</br>That paves the way for want, and chains, and woe!</br>The source of strength declines unseen away;</br>E'en the throne sinks in slow but sure decay:</br>The nation's wealth feeds many a distant shore;</br>Her men return to till her fields no more:</br>Accumulated debt o'erwhelms the state</br>And dark corruption hastens on her fate.</br>Coercion then but fans the people's ire;</br>That, smother'd, kindles for a fiercer fire!</br>And taxes, wrung from toil's unwilling hand,</br>Drain the last blood-drop from a wither'd land!</br>Then — whether myriads toil for bread in vain,</br>Till madden'd by despair, and want, and pain;</br>Or lifeless grandeur deck th' unpeopled ground,</br>Whelm'd in vast ruin falls the nation round,</br>And hostile bands devouring sweep along,</br>Fir'd with the thoughts of many a former wrong!</br>Or slav'ry binds the realm in hopeless chains;</br>Or lawless anarchy in riot reigns.</br>Whate'er the means — destruction waits the land—</br>And thousands perish by the vengeful hand!</br>Thus when besieging armies circle round,</br>And doom some towering fortress to the ground—</br>The miner saps the seat of strength below,</br>And tottering leaves the unsubstantial show—</br>Still proudly frown the towers and massive walls—</br>Till burst in wreck the baseless fabric falls!</br>Whose heaps of ruins, in their giant length</br>Speak its past glory and its former strength!

Ah!  ye, who rashly hurl the brands of war!</br>And toil to feed its flames in realms afar!</br>Who doom mankind to death and anguish there;</br>And destine realms to famine and despair!</br>Do ye not shudder at the tales of woe?</br>Does there no tear, when cities perish, flow?</br>Ye who at home in lux'ry sit, and plan</br>The fall of states, the agony of man—</br>Does fancy never picture to your souls</br>Corses that blacken in the flame that rolls?</br>Do ye ne'er dream you hear your victim's cries—</br>Nor see their restless shades in terror rise?</br>Does placid pleasure smile around your heads?</br>Is peace the guardian angel of your beds?</br>How long to you shall men their reason yield?</br>For your base passions seek the murd'rous field?</br>Devote their kind to all the woes of strife;</br>And dash away the little term of life?

Now let me turn my lonely wand'ring feet</br>Amidst yon ruins of a noble street!</br>What melancholy silence slumbers here,</br>Where busy tumult lately fill'd the ear.</br>Day-dreaming owls in desert chambers sleep;</br>And birds obscene thro' useless temples sweep—</br>Halls that resounded to the voice of bliss,</br>Now but reverberate the serpent's hiss!</br>Th' untrodden pavement, all with grass o'ergrown,</br>Shrouds reptile myriads curl'd beneath each stone.</br>No feet, save mine, remain to tread the ground;</br>No other voice invades the still profound;</br>Nor neighing steed, nor rattling wheel is heard;</br>Nor midnight sound, except the shrieking bird:</br>No more the proud Cathedral's deep-ton'd bell</br>Proclaims the circling hours with solemn swell—</br>No more the punctual tradesman marks the day;</br>Nor idler loiters his long hours away:</br>In vain the Sun his morning beam bestows;</br>Here none are left to rise from night's repose:</br>The Moon in vain her softer radiance pours;</br>None — none remain to hail the pensive hours;</br>Time treads his round unreckon'd and unknown;</br>And death-like silence claims this spot her own—</br>Here holds her speechless reign — here builds her midnight throne.

Proud e'en in ruins seems the legal hall,</br>Where sate, the Judge rever'd and lov'd by all;</br>In whom unbiass'd, stubborn truth was found—</br>Who would be faithful — though his monarch frown'd!</br>True to the spirit of his country's laws,</br>He listen'd to no quibbles, quirks, nor flaws:</br>When men, demanding justice, round him drew,</br>The peasant and the prince no difference knew—</br>His smile assur'd the injur'd and opprest—</br>His purity proclaim'd the guiltless blest!</br>The felon shrank from his deep-searching look,</br>And with dire presage of his sentence shook!</br>Th' intent, and not the deed alone, he saw;</br>And dared bid virtue triumph over law.</br>No widow twice petition'd him to hear;</br>No friendless orphan shed a useless tear;</br>Nor power nor gold avail'd to screen the vile;</br>Or tempt his frown where duty bade him smile.</br>The shield of age, the monitor of youth,</br>His mind he lent to find the hidden truth;</br>Not wont to glide the surface smoothly o'er—</br>But doubtful subjects deeply to explore.</br>Mercy alone could e'er his justice move;</br>Slow to condemn — yet ready to approve—</br>His manly firmness, and his virtuous fire,</br>E'en those who dreaded most, would still admire.</br>He knew the nation on his truth relied,</br>To guard her peace and on her rights decide;</br>And thousands placed their liberties and lands,</br>Without one fear, in his impartial hands.</br>What confidence o'er all his virtue shed</br>What praises settled on his honour'd head</br>If prayers, sincerely pour'd, may blessings be—</br>Most blest he was — for many a prayer had he!</br>Peace to his ashes!  he deserved the best—</br>His spirit long has found its heaven of rest.</br>How diff'rent he who oft that seat disgraced!</br>Thwarting the pleader with indecent haste;</br>Impatient in a cause he would not like—</br>His eye, like angry lightnings, seem'd to strike!</br>In him corruption, found a willing friend,</br>Her blackest usurpations to defend.</br>Opposing all improvements of the law—</br>His Prince's smile, the only light he saw!</br>Too much a courtier to be sternly just—</br>Too often sway'd by passion's stormy gust—</br>Proud, overbearing, curbing, ruling all;</br>His fiat thunder'd through the startl'd hall!</br>Who dared a Prince's follies — crimes — to show—</br>Found him nor judge nor counsellor — but foe!</br>Toiling for infamy to blast his name,</br>Hated he lived, and died bereft of fame.

Beside yon churchyard wall, his wonted stand,</br>A sightless beggar stretch'd his needy hand:</br>One changeless, short petition, met the ear,</br>Whene'er a passing footstep sounded near—</br>The simple prayer — "Have pity on the blind!"</br>Urged its full force to every feeling mind.</br>Nature to him did ne'er her beauties show!</br>Veil'd were the clouds above, and fields below!</br>When morning dawn'd — he hail'd no golden ray,</br>Nor mark'd the crimson of the closing day:</br>Nor saw the beam that warm'd his cheek at noon—</br>Nor knew from birth the lustre of the Moon!</br>Shape, figure, reach'd his sense by touch alone;</br>And all he felt not, was to him unknown;</br>Veil'd was the form that brush'd him as it past,</br>Or in his hand the boon of pity cast;</br>And when the thunder roll'd its peal on high—</br>The lightning flash'd not on his sightless eye!</br>Oft have I seen some neighbour's child bestow</br>A welcome trifle to relieve his woe.</br>Wise are those parents who so soon impart</br>The kindliest feelings to the infant heart!</br>Themselves, perchance, in fortune's changing hour,</br>May gladden in their sympathetic power.</br>Fix'd to that spot, in spite of wind and rain,</br>Food, home, and raiment, dubious to obtain—</br>So past his dull, unvaried life, away,</br>Unchang'd by gloom of night, or blaze of day!</br>If that may life be call'd, that cannot mark</br>The morn, or eve — one midnight, long and dark—</br>Yes — he had night — 'twas when his sorrow slept—</br>And morn — when from his still dark couch he crept!</br>All day his dog beside him stretch'd along,</br>Feeble in power, but in affection strong;</br>In all his master's joys, though few they were,</br>He had an equal and a constant share;</br>His wants and his commands alike he knew;</br>As patient s himself — as needy too!</br>With more than instinct led him home at night,</br>Relieving by his love the loss of sight;</br>His sole amusement, and his faithful guide,</br>He never wander'd from his master's side;</br>His piteous form — his want — his tatter'd vest—</br>Ne'er changed th' affection of that constant breast;</br>Nor would that honest brute have lov'd him more</br>Had gold embroider'd every garb he wore.</br>O!  thus denied the light of heaven to view—</br>What active sympathy from man is due!</br>Doom'd in dark listlessness to pass his days,</br>While manly vigour every limb displays;</br>Willing to labour — but without the power—</br>Pity his sole dependence every hour.</br>But now — where does he feel his midnight way?</br>Who soothes the sorrows of his sunless day?</br>Perchance, e'en of his dumb conductor reft,</br>He finds nor home, nor hand to aid him, left;</br>Till, sinking, as he roams from place to place,</br>He dies amidst the wreck he cannot trace.

Fall'n is the mansion, where the shivering poor</br>Once gather'd round the hospitable door:</br>The home of one, by all the needy lov'd,</br>Whom every plaint of woe to pity mov'd:</br>He had a hand to raise, a heart to bless,</br>Whene'er he found his fellow in distress.</br>Though to the joys of wealth and honor born,</br>He never from the humble turn'd with scorn—</br>And, though by princes favor'd, ne'er forgot</br>The secret sorrows of the lowly cot:</br>Not like the heartless, fashionably gay,</br>Too proud to help the wand'rer on his way:</br>From ghastly want he never turn'd aside,</br>Nor view'd the supplicant with lordly pride.</br>He cheer'd the dungeon where no sunbeam shone;</br>Sooth'd guilt's despair, and still'd the debtor's groan;</br>Burst from his limbs the iron links away,</br>And brought him hope, and liberty, and day.</br>Glowing with sympathy's unfading fire,—</br>The widow's guardian, and the orphan's sire;</br>Grief would to him an equal pang impart—</br>A tear — th' unfailing passport to his heart!</br>Unostentatious of the good he did,</br>He, when he could, his noblest actions hid.</br>When evening threw her shadows on the ground,</br>The secret haunts of woe he sought and found;</br>Where many fallen family he blest;</br>Too modest to solicit, though distrest!</br>Ah!  'tis by those, who once in sunshine dwelt,</br>Fate's dark'ning frown is most severely felt:</br>'Tis not the Prince, nor Peer, when fallen low,</br>Who bear the worst extremes of human woe—</br>A nation sympathises in their fate,</br>And many a wealthy friend unbars his gate—</br>'Tis not the vagrant and unalter'd poor,</br>Born in distress, and nurtur'd to endure—</br>As he, who lately hail'd the cheering light,</br>Mourns with intensest grief th' extinguish'd sight—</br>So they who once a competence enjoy'd,</br>Or in the sun of hope their powers employ'd;</br>Feel, when struck down to poverty and woe,</br>With tenfold force, the unexpected blow:</br>And die unseen, unaided, and alone;</br>Rather than make their wants and sorrows known.</br>When winter howl'd along the sunless air,</br>How many found their shelter in his care!</br>A mantle o'er their freezing limbs he threw;</br>And half disarm'd the coldest wind that blew:</br>Fix'd in his aim, by virtuous zeal inspir'd—</br>No perils check'd him, and no labours tir'd;</br>He brav'd the prison's pestilential breath;</br>And pour'd the prayer that sooth'd the pangs of death—</br>Though born to riches, luxury, and ease,</br>He past his days in scenes and toils like these;</br>And strove to plant in every youthful mind,</br>The principle of love to all mankind.</br>Thus, self-approving, and by thousands blest,</br>Sweet must have been the feelings of his breast.</br>So the kind Sun, by planets circl'd round,</br>Beams plenty, light, and joy on all around.</br>But now bereft of all his bounty's store,</br>His power to sooth and succour is no more;</br>Himself, perchance now wanting what he gave,</br>Despairing falls, without a friend to save.

Near where yon fallen column dents the ground,</br>A cheerful Mendicant was daily found;</br>A stormy life, with vigour, he had brav'd,</br>Till, round his brow the hoary ringlets wav'd:</br>He counted seasons, till his hopes retir'd;</br>Till sons were scatter'd, and till friends expir'd:</br>But, though his cheeks proclaim'd the lapse of years,</br>Their furrows never channel'd many tears!</br>A well-patched wallet, swinging at his side,</br>A scanty meal, at Nature's call, supplied:</br>Upheld by confident content, he smil'd,</br>While passing scenes his tedious hours beguil'd;</br>And if of food, for present use, possest,</br>He trusted Providence for all the rest.</br>Ev'n he, at times, a generous heart could show,</br>And give his alms to ease another's woe!</br>Oft' has a group of children round him stood,</br>Struck with his tatter'd vest, but merry mood;</br>Amaz'd to see him, though so poor, so glad;</br>For many a tale — and many a jest he had—</br>The young, he said, should succour one grown grey—</br>The aged — him become as old as they:</br>Thus his request he made to all apply,</br>Nor e'er neglected one who past him by.</br>He call'd no curses on the rich who frown'd;</br>But like a priest shower'd blessings all around;</br>Blest those who, cold to pity, heard him crave;</br>And doubly blest the friendly hand that gave.</br>What once had been a soldier's coat he wore;</br>To which in shape a likeness still it bore;</br>To him, it seem'd what it had earliest been—</br>Though scarce one thread of scarlet then was seen.</br>They who would stoop his varied tale to hear,</br>Might learn how some the ills of life can cheer;</br>And find, that, in the darkest waste below,</br>There still are beams to gild the path of woe:</br>His buoyant spirit rose o'er every ill;</br>And he had wit at need, and smiles at will.</br>Nor was it tales of mirth alone he knew—</br>He could talk philosophically too!</br>The rules and stratagems of war explain;</br>And plan the field where glory pil'd the slain:</br>Recall the wild and desperate feats of youth;</br>And paint past years with more than history's truth:</br>Describe the scenes of many a distant clime;</br>And pour a light upon the page of time.</br>Driv'n from this spot, where may he now appear?</br>Who now shall listen, and who now can cheer?

Within yon wall I see the ruin'd pile,</br>Where first the rescued orphan learn'd to smile:</br>Where oft', at pastime's licens'd hours, the boys</br>Burst from confinement with exulting noise;</br>The task forgot, as they impell'd the ball,</br>Oft' seen revolving high above the wall.</br>Delighted have I stood to mark their sport</br>Within the limits of yon spacious court:</br>Some ran from those who watch'd their steps, to hide;</br>Some walk'd in life's first friendship, side by side;</br>Or spread the circle with united hands;</br>Or fought the mimic field, in hostile bands.</br>Ev'n they their parties form'd for love or strife—</br>In peace or war — a miniature of life!</br>Till the unwelcome bell recall'd to school,</br>Once more to bend to order and to rule:</br>Then ceased the game; each head dejected hung;</br>And muttering sorrow murmur'd from each tongue:</br>As if a sudden cloud had ris'n to shed;</br>O'er a bright day, a shadow deep and dread—</br>Till hope, that paints to every human eye,</br>Show'd the next hour for play, and show'd it nigh.</br>Tutor'd for commerce, or refin'd for art,</br>There emulation first inspir'd the heart,</br>That often with a pure, undying flame,</br>Impell'd them on to fortune and to fame:</br>While knowledge open'd to their mental eyes</br>Her ample stores, and bade them learn and rise.</br>Ill-fated boys!  here ye have play'd your last!</br>Here all your pleasures, all your hopes are past!</br>Reft by the sword from all the joys of life,</br>Victims of statesmen's folly — kingly strife;</br>Perchance, around this ruin'd realm ye roam,</br>Without a tutor, and without a home,</br>Imploring aid — where aid is found no more—</br>Forgetting all that you had learn'd before—</br>And chang'd to vagrants, who had lived and died,</br>Your country's honor, and your teachers' pride.

Lone stands the Theatre, whose raptur'd crowd,</br>Or fix'd in silence, or applauding loud,</br>Beheld the mimic scene before them pass,</br>And look'd on life as in a magic glass—</br>Where man, instructed by the Poet's lays,</br>Compared the present with departed days;</br>Where forests, caverns, mountains, met the sight—</br>Clothed in the blaze of day, or gloom of night:</br>While palaces, enchanted, seem'd to rise;</br>And chambers — prisons — open'd on the eyes!</br>As there some vast creative power had been,</br>That out of nothing form'd the instant scene.</br>There the beholder, borne on fancy's wing,</br>Saw distant realms, and changing seasons spring—</br>Now view'd Arabia's burning desert glow;</br>And now the Polar waste of ice and snow—</br>And now the ocean, rising into wrath,</br>O'er which the lightning cleav'd its fiery path;</br>And heard the thunder rolling through the storm;</br>Still viewing nature in each varied form—</br>While, as by magic, suddenly appear—</br>Men, cities, of another hemisphere:</br>Isles where the savage lurks for human prey—</br>And armies marching in their long array—</br>Beholding, in that transient space of time,</br>The colour and the garb of every clime:</br>While the unravell'd plot held every sense</br>In breathless expectation, and suspense.</br>There the swift hours resistless laughter sped;</br>And many a tear at mimic woe was shed;</br>There poetry display'd her highest pow'rs;</br>And scenic fascination charm'd the hours;</br>While music round in sweetest echoes stole,</br>Rais'd the affections, and inspired the soul!</br>What follies have been there by wit display'd!</br>What scenes, what characters, from life portray'd!</br>Man, as he really is, unmask'd appear'd;</br>Admir'd, or scorn'd; detested, or rever'd.</br>There suff'ring virtue struggled with distress,</br>Yet proved at last, her power alone can bless:</br>While the dire passions, raging to the sight,</br>Taught man to shun their vortex with affright—</br>Anger, with swelling cheek, and looks of fire;</br>And dark Revenge, that fann'd her gathering ire;</br>And Fear, with rolling eye, and struggling breath—</br>And baffled Love — whose only hope was death!</br>Sorrow that forc'd the genuine tear to flow;</br>And Jealousy that fed upon its woe—</br>Despair, that dar'd the last — the worst — to brave;</br>And Hate, that dogg'd its victim to the grave—</br>These, in succession, past before the view,</br>In all their native energy and hue!</br>Yes!  scenes like these a generous warmth impart;</br>And tune to sympathy the soften'd heart:</br>Expand the mind — give brightness to its fire—</br>And love of virtue and of fame inspire;</br>Proud scene of art!  Alas!  for ever fled!</br>No laughter echoes, and no tears are shed:</br>No mimic captive groans, no hero dies,</br>No tyrant threatens, and no lover sighs:</br>Thalia 'midst the ruins walks in tears;</br>And in unfeign'd despair Melpomene appears.

Ye searching antiquaries!  here behold</br>The fate of relics, valued more than gold!</br>Gone are the ancient scraps that charm'd your eyes—</br>Stretch'd in the dust your lov'd Museum lies!</br>Where doubtful fragments proudly were secur'd,</br>If haply found in classic ground immur'd.</br>Coins, that scarce show'd the shadow of a head;</br>Or hieroglyphics, that were all but fled;</br>And stones, with characters unknown and rude;</br>With transport and astonishment were view'd!</br>Inquiring virtuosi gather'd round,</br>Big with conjectures and remarks profound:</br>Sometimes a parchment, worn by damp or time,</br>A monkish legend, or a mystic rhyme—</br>Before them spread its almost hidden lore;</br>And minds were strain'd its meaning to explore.</br>Some thought they saw unfolded to their view</br>A field of hist'ry, and of science too;</br>And hopes of fortune and of fame enjoy'd,</br>That deeper search but scatter'd and destroy'd.</br>Their eager eyes devour'd an ancient seal;</br>They loved a medal better than a meal!</br>The feather'd kingdom rang'd the shelves along,</br>With all their brilliant plumes, but reft of song;</br>Like gaudy coxcombs, bright in outward shape,</br>The image of the nobler man they ape.</br>There stood the Lion, monarch of the plain,</br>And there the Tiger, who scarce own'd his reign:</br>Vipers, of forms repulsive, curl'd in glass,</br>That, arm'd with death, once lurk'd beneath the grass:</br>Insects, of countless species, swarm'd around;</br>And ocean's wrecks in inland mountains found:</br>And animals extinct, now turn'd to stone,</br>The relics of a race for ever gone:</br>Embalm'd by nature — coffin'd in a rock—</br>Preserv'd through every elemental shock;</br>The remnants of a former world to show,</br>'Ere earth's convulsions laid their species low.</br>The rarest, loveliest shells, from distant shores;</br>Metals and petrifactions, gems' and ores;</br>The finest works of nature and of art</br>Were treasur'd there in one unrivall'd mart;</br>The bust, that sav'd from death some honor'd face;</br>And pictures, all but breathing life and grace:</br>While rude designs, from savage nations brought,</br>Display'd the dawn of art's awaking thought:</br>And manuscripts, of many an age and clime,</br>There rescu'd from the mould'ring touch of time,</br>Show'd, as they past from barbarous to refin'd,</br>The growth of learning, and the march of mind.</br>There were preserv'd the charters of the land;</br>Wrung from some despot by a patriot band:</br>And the long, tedious toils, of letter'd men;</br>And poems, dash'd from genius' fiery pen!</br>And there were wrecks from Egypt's ruin'd coast,</br>Colossal forms no later age can boast:</br>Whose mountain temples, and whose piles of stone</br>Stand in huge magnitude, unmatch'd, alone</br>Whose perfect finish, and extensive plan,</br>Surpass the rivalship of modern man:</br>Works that the wrath of ages have defied;</br>Performed by man in his gigantic pride:</br>Uniting, in their adamantine length,</br>His mortal science with supernal strength!</br>Whose sacred symbols lock'd in midnight gloom</br>The knowledge of the past, a letter'd tomb—</br>By men of learning vainly ponder'd o'er,</br>In hopes the marble volumes to explore:</br>Now clos'd from all research, in mystic night,</br>Unless a master key-stone spring to light.</br>But proudest stood the sculptor's gems of art,</br>Those idols worshipp'd by the wisest heart;</br>And highest in the scale, fall'n Greece!  were thine;</br>Decreed o'er all competitors to shine</br>Thou still hast left, to shame each feebler land,</br>The living marbles of thy matchless hand;</br>Which seem to boast the immortality,</br>Their full, complete perfection, caught from thee!</br>Looking as if sense, feeling, thought, were there—</br>This smiling love — that shrinking in despair!</br>Here flashing anger; and there frowning hate;</br>As though they stood the arbiters of fate—</br>This, all but stepping from its pedestal—</br>That, as if starting back, afraid to fall!</br>Here smiled a Venus, rich in every grace,</br>That mortal form could show of limb and face;</br>And there the serpents coil'd before the eye,</br>Till the beholder almost turn'd to fly!</br>These, Urburgh, were thy precious gems; and these</br>Thy riches brought thee over distant seas;</br>Or, in thy day of pride, by battle won,</br>Here shed the light of art's reviving sun:</br>But now in fragments strew'd by barbarous hands,</br>Or borne as trophied spoils to distant lands:</br>Passing, as power removes, from clime to clime;</br>Till lost for ever in the gulph of time.

Here too the sister art of Painting shone,</br>In all the charms peculiarly her own.</br>When through the long, light gallery, I pac'd,</br>And forms of every shape and colour trac'd;</br>I seem'd to feel as on some fairy ground,</br>Where new creations breath'd and bloom'd around:</br>Where every figure fancy could divine;</br>And every tint that art could lend to shine—</br>And every scene that genius, taste, could show;</br>Embodying the beautiful below—</br>Enchain'd the ling'ring sight, whose raptur'd sense</br>Alone inspir'd the soul with joy intense.</br>In fancy 'twas another world, that gave</br>To view the mighty who had past the grave—</br>Vision'd in thought — I seem'd myself to find</br>Among the greatest — brightest of mankind!</br>And look'd as on the living forms of men,</br>Whom mortal tongue could never greet again:</br>And held communion with the wise and just,</br>Whose bones for ages had been strew'd in dust!</br>Still — still remember'd — e'en in sorrow dear—</br>The shadows of those beauteous works appear;</br>Which here a nation's admiration drew,</br>And fann'd the glorious pride from whence they grew!</br>In memory yet full many a picture lives;</br>Glowing in all the fire that genius gives:</br>I see the forms that seem to think — to move—</br>Swelling in wrath — or melting into love!</br>The battle rages — flashes on the wall!</br>And armies seem to close, and squadrons fall!</br>Th' assassin's dagger drinks his victim's blood—</br>The vessel sinks beneath the whelming flood:</br>The ambush'd lion springs upon the steed;</br>Stiff'ning in fear the form he dooms to bleed!</br>And powers supernal glide beneath the storm,</br>Whom demon passions darken and deform!</br>The lovely landscape lengthens on the sight,</br>In noon's warm flush, or morning's golden light;</br>O'er eve's soft scene the crimson clouds are driven,</br>In all the varied drapery of heaven:</br>The distant mountains melt into the hue</br>That veils the horizon's verge in misty blue;</br>Or, pour'd upon the water, Dian's beam</br>Arrays in silver light the slumb'ring stream.</br>Th' historic scene its silent story speaks—</br>His hate the tyrant on the patriot wreaks</br>What passions in the crowded canvass glow!</br>Each figure seems to act as once below—</br>Till the whole tale of pity, love, or ire,</br>Bursts on the soul in characters of fire!</br>And more than e'en remembrance can restore—</br>Here have I seen, but now can see no more.</br>Yet those whose treasur'd beauties still survive,</br>Memory in sorrow long shall keep alive;</br>Long as one shadow of the past remains—</br>Long as the spirit drags its earthly chains.</br>Yet still the soul shall bless that faithful power,</br>That keeps some charm to sooth the present hour;</br>That rescues from the past, when life was bright,</br>Some form to cheer its dim succeeding night;</br>And gives the spirit, else of all bereft,</br>The only beam a darken'd fate has left.</br>So the worn traveller, fix'd at home at last,</br>Reviews the brightest scenes through which he past;</br>And thither borne on fancy's wing of light,</br>Ponders their beauties with renew'd delight.

Far different scene did yon recess display—</br>Where, veil'd in clouds of smoke that darken'd day,</br>A crowded, noisy Manufactory stood;</br>A source of public or of private good.</br>There did a toiling race their lives employ,</br>And thence arose each dearly purchas'd joy:</br>The long — long hours, in changeless dullness, past;</br>Each day, each year, a picture of the last—</br>The drear, uninteresting task, the same;</br>Life, scarce relieved by pleasure, hope, or fame.</br>There did they hasten soon as morning rose;</br>And there were chain'd beyond the evening's close:</br>From earliest youth the beaten path they trod;</br>Nor left it — but to mingle with the sod.</br>For them the sweets of nature bloom'd in vain:</br>The scented valley, and the breezy plain;</br>Scarce for their eyes the golden clouds appear'd—</br>Nor for their feet the hills their summits rear'd—</br>Scarce time could father spare t' embrace his child—</br>Few days of joy a darken'd year beguil'd;</br>'Twas toil — 'twas sleep — a hurried meal — a breath;</br>A cold, dark, caged existence, closed by death;</br>There droop'd the fetter'd soul; the gifted mind,</br>Sunk to the lowest level of its kind;</br>And feeling that her wings could never soar,</br>Her pinions clos'd, and thought of flight no more!</br>O!  surely, bounteous Heav'n could ne'er decree</br>Such gloom should shroud the spirit's brilliancy:</br>Did never that ethereal light bestow</br>To die in darkness, or to set in woe!</br>The glorious hand that plac'd the Sun on high,</br>Gave it to glow — to shine — for every eye:</br>No niggard of his boon, he shower'd on earth</br>Blessings for all, the right of all by birth;</br>Nor e'er intended that incessant toil</br>Should freeze the heart's last hope, the lip's last smile.</br>And truth proclaims that land's unnatural state,</br>Where half the people sink in wayward fate;</br>Who sleep to dream of joy that ne'er arrives;</br>And only wake to labour through their lives:</br>Where hoary age is torn from rest away,</br>And fetter'd childhood weeps its loss of play;</br>And manhood sees his years of prime expire,</br>As the Sun wastes on desert sands his fire.</br>The state's demands, each year increasing, tore</br>From the despairing labourers half their store;</br>And left them in their ravag'd homes to feel</br>The desolating wounds they could not heal!</br>Now freed too late, perchance the hostile change</br>But leaves them houseless wanderers to range.
